timeline.message:
GH-2603 Migrate vocabularies to AbstractNamespace/IRI factory methods

Signed-off-by: Alessandro Bollini <22@metreeca.com>

timeline.bodyText: Why are we adding factory methods to the class itself? This will be problematic to support. For example concrete subclasses will have their own factories, but if you do MyConcreteBNode.createBNode you suddenly get a GenericBNode instance again. It also somewhat defeats the purpose of having a separate ValueFactory.
timeline.author: jeenbroekstra

replies.bodyText: No problem reverting to package-visible constructors.
replies.author: knoan

timeline.bodyText: Same here. Let's not put factory methods in the abstract classes themselves.
timeline.author: jeenbroekstra
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -26,6 +23,61 @@
 
 	private static final long serialVersionUID = 7799969821538513046L;
 
+	/**
+	 * Creates a new IRI value.
+	 *
+	 * @param iri the string representation of the IRI
+	 * 
+	 * @return a new generic IRI value
+	 * 
+	 * @throws NullPointerException     if {@code iri} is {@code null}
+	 * @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code iri} is not an absolute IRI
+	 */
+	public static IRI createIRI(String iri) {

timeline.bodyText: I think this may be over-optimising things somewhat. Keep in mind that most database implementations will have their own ValueFactory (and therefore own IRI) implementations.
timeline.author: jeenbroekstra

replies.bodyText: More of a matter of convenience, as the merging/splitting logic is reversed in the two cases, but I'll review the matter.
replies.author: knoan

timeline.message:
GH-2603 Add o.e.r.mode.base.AbstractValueFactory

Signed-off-by: Alessandro Bollini <22@metreeca.com>

GH-2603 Add o.e.r.mode.base.AbstractValueFactory

Signed-off-by: Alessandro Bollini <22@metreeca.com>

timeline.bodyText:
This is somewhat minor (so don't feel the need to immediately take these out again), but: open question (to @hmottestad and @barthanssens as well) - what's your opinion on the usefulness of this kind of "visual divider" commenting? I've been taking most of the legacy marker comment blocks ("constructors" / "public methods") etc out because they tend to get malformed and also just wrong over time (people putting private methods in the public methods bit etc).
I'm personally not in favor of adding this kind of thing at all. But if we feel there's value in organising code this way then I'd like a consistent style adopted, at least.
timeline.author: jeenbroekstra

replies.bodyText:
When working with a folding code editor on a complex class, I find it useful to be able to visually group related methods.
This particular graphic solution is probably too imposing: my personal suggestion would be to relax formatting rules to allow for two consecutive blank lines as in the attached example.
replies.author: knoan

replies.bodyText: @knoan fwiw I put this up for discussion and seeing if there are some best practices we can agree upon on the rdf4j-dev mailinglist, feel free to chime in there. For now I'm fine with just some developer discretion, as in: feel free to use what you think makes the code easier to read / maintain, as long as nobody objects you're good :)
replies.author: jeenbroekstra

timeline.bodyText: I've just realized that this new class was introduced, but there's no relation to the existing AbstractValueFactory. I'll take a look at that, we may want to have the old class inherit from the new and/or deprecate it.
timeline.author: jeenbroekstra
jeenbroekstra

replies.author: knoan

replies.bodyText: I don't think we have a consistent standard for this throughout the project - I tend to prefer the more compact form myself but there's some room for personal preference here :)
replies.author: jeenbroekstra

timeline.bodyText: Where does this come from? I've never seen this particular warning / annotation before.
timeline.author: jeenbroekstra

replies.bodyText: Technically speaking that annotation prevents IntelliJ automated QA from complaining about the use of Date and Calendar. Probably also useful as a human-readable reminder of the need to upgrade (e.g. #2563).
replies.author: knoan

timeline.bodyText: Could we rewrite this using if...else instead of a collection of ternary operators? It will be easier to read I think.
timeline.author: jeenbroekstra

timeline.bodyText: We already have a BooleanLiteral class. Do we need this?
timeline.author: jeenbroekstra

timeline.bodyText: I genuinely don't understand what this comment means (also not sure I understand what the !!! signifies).
timeline.author: jeenbroekstra

replies.bodyText: !!!comments are just a leftover personal annotations, now removed or replaced with TODO comments.
replies.author: knoan

replies.bodyText:
Objects.hash() is a variadic method: invoking it requires the instantiation of an array containing arguments, which in the context of .hashCode() has a large performance impact (more than 25% according to my rough figures).
Left a comment just as a reminder for future review: we are currently not at liberty of redefining hashing, as already discussed elsewhere.
replies.author: knoan

timeline.message:
GH-2603 Refactor after code review

Signed-off-by: Alessandro Bollini <22@metreeca.com>

GH-2603 marked old AbstractValueFactory deprecated

- its implementation will eventually be moved to SimpleValueFactory
- relation between this and the new AbstractValueFactory in model-api
tbd.
